1121929895800557568.text: This is the starting line. We don’t know where finish line is tho. Maybe USDT is printing $ and buying private islands. Maybe they’re entrepreneurs trying to win in a world turned against them. I will give 1 piece of legal advice: don't lie about things. It makes everything worse

1121929894156328960.text: In any case, this *is* fraud – full stop. You may be perfectly solvent, but lying to people gets attention of authorities – fuller stop. And now the gears of investigative and regulatory intervention spring to life.pic.twitter.com/7mTzxKmbFG

1121929888473026560.text: Maybe focusing on money-printing is watching the tree and missing the forest. Even if printing wasn't happening, what other shadiness was going on or will go on?

1121929887378313216.text:
I also just read ~50 pages from a state regulator, presumably w/ more resources, and even they could only make two interesting factual assertions without seeking a court order:

1. At one point in recent history Tether was not backed 1:1

2. Tether lied about it.

1121929886136823809.text: But, as other detractors have pointed out, this anonymous handle of uncertain education, background, resources, and training, and likely little access to insider information, was not vindicated on the claim of money-printing.

1121929885016920064.text: So back to @Bitfinexed claims. At root, he was showing that this climate was available. The NYAG documents confirm that, though this was pretty clear from early on.

1121929883649658880.text: Side note: NYAG is NOT forcing BFX to keep its doors open. That’s not how injunctions (or accounting) work. If I'm insolvent, I can't stay open just because a regulator holds a gun to my head.https://twitter.com/alistairmilne/status/1121561718440779776 …

1121929882504548352.text: This is where NYAG steps in “to protect NY investors.” The injunction prevents them from increasing the risk of this happening by preventing USDT from absorbing more risk from BFX. They prefer isolated damage than exponentially combined damage. We probably do too.

1121929881321758721.text: What’s worse for crypto: The loss of either BFX or USDT (or maybe both at different times)? Or the loss of both large institutions simultaneously? (nevermind anyone else holding USDT anywhere or trading on BFX).

1121929880206069761.text: So in this situation, you have the potential for a two-for-one loss. The owners have shown that a run on one institution can cause them to try to absorb the risk into the other. It might have actually worked this time, too. But who knows next time?

1121929878775820288.text: I would suspect that a non-conflicted lender would want a different arrangement. I also would suspect that any fractional reserve lending bank would diversify its loans, rather than only give them to a distressed exchange.

1121929877546885121.text: We can’t tell whether the loan was made on just terms when negotiated under a conflict of interest. Were BFX to default on its loan (presumably because insolvent), USDT would only have 60,000 ~worthless shares to make up the dif on its “1:1 backed coin.”

1121929876435398656.text: So this is what is scary about this instance. We have BFX and USDT, two of the largest institutions in crypto, owned by the same people. And they have shown that they are willing to shift risk around to avoid either’s collapse.

1121929875302928384.text: Wildcat banks’ average lifespan was 5 years. They were frequently mismanaged and would engage in various degrees of fraud and uninformed reserve lending. Half of them failed, with a third due to failure to redeem their notes.

1121929874157920257.text: At heart of free banking were wildcat banks. There was no central bank in charge of currency, so individual banks collectively controlled $ supply by issuing their own notes on par with a dollar that could be exchanged for a dollar’s worth of other notes/assets. Sound familiar?

1121929872991903744.text: But in a way this shows we’re in a mini-free-banking period. Free banking was an era marked by frequent recessions and banking panics every 5-20 years caused by lightly regulated banks and a highly reactive population prone running after any kind of alarming news. Sound familiar?

1120074123168759808.text: So summary: FinCEN is using new label to hit individuals. This is not itself problematic, but we don't know where the line ends and they're moving further from explicitly intentionally bad behavior by defendants. Those in DeFi and DEX communities may want to keep an eye on this

1120074122342494209.text:
CC arg: https://coincenter.org/files/e-cash-dex-constitution.pdf …

Also note: Mr. Powers more or less "pled" to punishment. Had he fought in court, his lawyers likely would make a version of CC's argument to get him off. FinCEN decisions like this arent binding law, but they're all we got until someone challenges

1120074121579077632.text: But if they do, @coincenter makes passionate arg for why "yes" could violate the 1st and 4th amendments. Counter-arg would gets into nuance of 3PD and convoluted discussion of whether code and $ = speech. But CC isn't "wrong," but rather presents one strong side to an issue

1120074120866091008.text: To me, this is most interesting aspect of the guidance decision. Does selling substantial amounts on DEX create FinCEN liability for me as an individual? Practical answer is we might not ever know: DEXs aren't in as much use as LocalBTC or in-person OTC. Maybe will never be (?)

1120074120190758912.text: I have even less knowledge of customers than LocalBTC cases (known drug dealers) or Mr. Powers (knowledge of Silk Road and Tor involvement). Is this lack of knowledge a legal shield or is it a component of suspecting DEX users are hiding something (like FinCEN implies)?

1120074119318425600.text: So what happens for DEX users? Similar to LocalBTC and BitcoinTalk cases, there's no centralized intermediary that helps w/ AML efforts. Indeed, I am selling directly to others P2P. Am I marketing my exchange services when I list to sell on RadarRelay?

1120074118743781377.text: From a policy standpoint, this is...strange. If I sell 5 BTCs to my dad because he's interested in tech but not sophisticated enough to use CoinBase, am I required to file a CTR? I probably didn't "market" to him, so no, but I cant find a brightline for such in this guidance.

1120074118051684352.text: The other difference is the application of the "P2P exchanger" label, which seems to mean they did more than just buy, but also sold, bitcoin on a P2P basis. AFAIK this is the first time FinCEN applied that label, which it defines without citation in this announcement.

1120074117305159680.text: This also may be the difference in penalties. LocalBTC cases usually carried prison time. Mr. Powers got off with a relatively light $35k fine and promise not to do it (or act as a bank) anymore.

1120074116436856833.text: As @msantoriESQ points out, there is some hypocrisy in emphasizing that using TOR is not by itself suspicious but heavily basing the decision on users' [at]tormail email address as possible indicia of criminal activityhttps://twitter.com/msantoriESQ/status/1119260466445004801 …

1120074115707068416.text: 1 dif in this case is extent of "bad behavior" linked to defendant. LocalBTC cases had knowing connection to drug dealers and clear money laundering. Mr. Powers, OTOH, transacted with TOR + Silk Road users, which maybe suspicious enough for a SAR but not smoking gun like others

1073394653838200833.text: If any other chains are reading this, I highly suggest looking at efforts from those and similar types of individuals. Their success/failures are publicly documented, and you can save a lot of time in catch-up from learning from their mistakes

1073394653007732737.text: I hope some can catch up (especially if Ethereum can't get better at TXs). But the value of Eth's organization comes not just from Vitalik, but through efforts of not-so-prominent community members like @jemenger @MPtherealMVP @greg_colvin @econoar @bmann.

1073394652370284544.text: Ethereum is 3 years ahead in community organization. Thats more important *right now* than txs or learning curve. If I need help with node-support, there's support. Same for wallets, ux, legal, product mgmt, etc. At minimum, other chains need to b as adv. to consider migration

1073394650839318528.text: If we reach a point where learning curve or tx throughput is a major obstacle, we will switch. I believe in decentralization, but I'm not a purist and am willing to sacrifice some idealism to meet the needs of my users.

1073394649874612224.text: I don't speak for others, but dApps I work on's problem is not tx throughput or dev talent. We don't have enough users to need more txs (yet) and I like devs who have had to learn solidity because they tend to understand contracts/decentralization better than neophyte legacy devs

1073394648930893824.text: New chains focus on tx throughput and lower developer learning curves. That such an exodus has not occurred yet indicates the major problems dApp-builders are currently facing is not just tx throughput or learning curve.

1073394648154927106.text: Reality: dApps on Ethereum have ~3 year head start on those on any other platform. Most dApp-builders are more chain-agnostic than Twitter might lead you to believe. If another chain is presented with tangible benefits, we would see a large exodus of dApps to that new chain

1048010096477761536.text: Anyways, while many of you hare TA charts and pray for a bull run, this is why I'm still here. Fascination with the fall of the world....and the re-building. Thank you for reading /fin

1048010095160750080.text: That's why governance must be carefully considered in both corporate and blockchain contexts. They both may be the next wave of sovereigns as we have ever known them. 23/

1048010094242193408.text: Or maybe something else. It's difficult to predict, but even more interesting is maybe the idea of citizenship after the dust settles. Who will you "belong to" when power re-centralizes again? Or will it even? 22/

1048010093277589504.text: So what comes next? Is it transnational organizations like Facebook, Cartels, or other international power brokers that take the place of the Church? Do they merge into one giant mega-corp? Or is it blockchains? With governances of bitcoin vs. eth vs. monero etc? 21/

1048010091205550080.text: Imagine as the free circulation of wealth and value start to take hold like the internet already has 20/pic.twitter.com/MAZLQWvBdj

1048010090194726912.text: In fact we already see it. Weaker systems collapse and are still in periods of instability. The Arab Spring, Brexit, rise of outsiders in Bernie and Trump, instability in SE China can be credited to social media and internet. Sovereigns are even accusing each other of hacking 19/

1048010089200738304.text: Fall of geographic sovereignty may not be pleasant. It may be violent. Maybe not, the virtues of peace have also spread the world, maybe revolution will follow suit? Who knows? It may be scary, but it also almost feels natural/impossible to resist with this historical pattern 18/

1048010088298893312.text: To try to sell the idea that the movement of information and wealth across borders is evil is a clear strategy for a regime based on control within borders. We can expect more political accusations against Facebook, Twitter, Bitcoin, and non-compliant exchanges. 17/

1048010087279652864.text: When information and money can instantly flow around the world, why have borders? Perhaps it's not surprising that authoritative threats recently center around immigration, drug running, international commerce, and other ecosystems that are inherently globalist. 16/

1048010086411423744.text: The threat this time is to geographic sovereignty. Post-enlightenment, power was enforced because it was not convenient to communicate or send wealth across borders. Radio waves and hard cash/debt could be contained inside borders. 15/

1048010085153165312.text: Almost exactly like the printing press and double-entry ledger system in the renaissance, the internet also spawned the publication/circulation of an idea of an immutable ledger outside of central control. We have only touched the tip of how that threatens global hierarchy 14/

1048010083945263104.text: With the internet, we again see a release of centralized controls on information. Bloggers, hackers, and social media platforms are too numerous to control. Accusations of foreign interference and even warfare via the internet represent threats to centralized powers. 13/

1048010082921795584.text: Societies globally struggled with these rapid changes. But ultimately the circulation of information and wealth was re-organized (through mass-media channels and banking systems, respectively). And with them, centralized controls re-formed. 12/

1048010081986465792.text: Rediscovery of science and philosophy led to even more advancement later. W/ newly-rediscovered ideas of physics/engineering, industrialization largely replaced need 4 unpaid labor (already dubious 2 enlightenment philosophers). Slavery was abolished in most nations mid-1800s 11/

1048010081114046464.text: The centralized powers had lost control 2 of the 3 pillars that maintained their influence. And the western world has never looked back. 10/

1048010080002560001.text: As information and wealth continued to circulate, more and more factions of centralized control were called into question. By the end of the next century, different flavors of democracy or parliamentarianism had infected most western nation-states. 9/

1048010079142731777.text: The people no longer relied on the Church to help transmit information or money. They could do it themselves. 8/

1048010078064795648.text: Along with Martin Luther, the ability to spread information and to learn swept Europe. The concepts double-entry accounting system, in use among a select few in Europe since the 1100s, was codified in written form by Paccioli in 1494 7/

1048010076793925632.text: Soon the masses could communicate long distances and could organize. And more importantly, they could learn and they could question authority. It's no coincidence that Martin Luther effectively divided the church by posting _written_ complaints within two generations. 6/

1048010075850166272.text: But Constantinople's fall coincided with one key factor: Gutenberg inventing the printing press. With ease of making materials to both learn to read and to replicate ideas in fixed form to communicate further, the Vatican struggled prevent the masses from spreading information 5/

1048010074973597696.text: In other words, even with scrolls, literacy was difficult to teach given inefficiency of writing things down 4/

1048010073690144768.text: Constantinople's fall (and consequent spread of monks around Europe) is credited as inspiring Renaissance intellectualism. While true, the monks' spread of Aristotle, Plato, Euclid, and Archamedes was limited by hand-written manuscripts and  unreliability of word of mouth. 3/

1048010072662495232.text: Middle ages saw power centralized around the church (namely Vatican). The Vatican controlled the flow of 3 things: information, wealth, and military. Literacy, high standard of living, and weaponry were concentrated in a noble few, while the rest provided for them 2/

1048010070296940544.text: The renaissance was a transition from Western lord-serf feudalism of the late middle ages into the early stages of democracies (and later industrial revolution). While many focus on it as the golden age of learning/art, others see it as the result of technological advancement 1/pic.twitter.com/8NSW8GeSWI
